page.title: 04ECOLOGY 2
page.content: THE NATIONAL TRUST IS PRESERVING SMALL SITES OF MEADOW FLOWERS. SPECIES FOUND IN COLONIES INCLUDE BLUEBELL, VIOLET, MEADOW CRANESBILL, CAMPIONS, LADY SMOCK AND IN MOIST PLACES SOAPWORT, FORGET-ME-NOT, MEADOWSWEET, WILD ARUM AND SEDGES. HIMALAYAN BALSAM COVERS THE RIVER BANKS IN SUMMER SPREADING THROUGHOUT THE BLOCK. ON ROADSIDE VERGES ARE FOUND KNAPWEED, MAYWEED, MUSK-THISTLE, TANSEY, MUGWORT, YARROW, BURDOCK, MALLOW, VETCHES, BETONY,WELD, SILVERWEED, WOODY NIGHTSHADE, LADIES' MANTLE,AND HERB ROBERT.PRIMROSES AND COWSLIPS ARE RARE AND FERNS AND BRACKEN HAVE DISAPPEARED.HARES AND RABBITS ARE INCREASING IN NUMBER.GREY SQUIRRELS ARE A PEST.FOXES ARE HUNTED AND PHEASATS REARED FOR SHOOTING MALLARD AND TEAL BREED ON THE RIVERS AND FIVE SPECIES OF BAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AT BENINGBROUGH.
